title: EUI-64 encoding in X.509
body:
Is it specified somewhere how an EUI-64 in encoded to a text string for use in X.509. In that case we should refer to that specification.

If not, we should specify that we assume the EUI-64 is encoded as
xx-xx-xx-xx-x-xx-xx-xx

title: Encoding of FQDN
body:
The current specification just says that FQDN is encoded as a text string. 
Is the ASN.1 shema correct for FQDN? RFC 7925 talkes about dNSName.

title: Curve25519 should not be point compressed....
Specify exactly how DER encoded issuer is encoded into a CBOR map and back again.
ASN.1 for issuer in Appendix B
body: Currently the ASN.1 says that issuer contains a single text string.

title: EUI-64 in certificates and MAC Address randomization
body:
EUI-64 is often created from 48-bit MAC addresses. Having a fixed MAC address goes against the current trend of MAC Address randomization.

- Should IoT devices always use EUI-64 in certificates?
- Should the EUI-64 be derived from the 48-bit MAC addresses?
- Should IoT devices use MAC Address randomization?

title: EUI-64 optimizations
body:
Should we optimize for any specific EUI-64 format. Are EUI-64 of the forms 
xx-xx-xx-FF-FE-xx-xx-xx
xx-xx-xx-FF-FF-xx-xx-xx

common in X.509 certificates? If so the most common form should be encoded to a byte string of 6 bytes. If both are somewhat common, the second most common could be encoded as a byte string of 7 bytes.

EUI-48, MAC-48, and 48-bit MAC address are all somewhat different. Mappings of EUI-48 and MAC-48 are deprecated according to IEEE so any such mapping should not be encouraged. Unclear if mapping from 48-bit MAC address is deprecated.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address:

To convert a MAC-48 into an EUI-64, copy the organizationally unique identifier (OUI), append the two octets FF-FF and then copy the organization-specified extension identifier. To convert an EUI-48 into an EUI-64, the same process is used, but the sequence inserted is FF-FE.[5] In both cases, the process could be trivially reversed when necessary. Organizations issuing EUI-64s were cautioned against issuing identifiers that could be confused with these forms.

IEEE says that:
https://standards.ieee.org/content/dam/ieee-standards/standards/web/documents/tutorials/eui.pdf

The subtle difference between MAC-48 and EUI-48 was not well understood, so the term EUI-48 is now used for both uses, and the term MAC-48 identifier is now obsolete. . (The IEEE RAC is not aware of any cases, but if MAC-48 is used as the name for any 48-bit MAC address, then EUI-48 is not the appropriate replacement term for MAC-48, as EUI-48 only refers to individual,
universally/globally unique network addresses.)

Mapping an EUI-48 to an EUI-64 is deprecated. The mapping is described here
for historical reasons.

title: Is pathLenConstraint mandatory to support in RFC 7925
Are all possible combinations of extensions possible?
Can 'critical' be encoded as a single bit?
body:
Or do we need to encode three options
- Absent
- Present and false
- Present and true

title: More specific ASN.1?
body: Current ASN.1 in appendix accepts all algorithms and extentions. Should the ASN.1 be made more specific?

title: ASN.1 AlgorithmIdentifier is prime256v1 only
ASN.1 SignatureIdentifier is ecdsa-with-SHA256 only
Upper or lower case for hex strings.
body: Should pick one, currently both are used.

title: Provide issuer public key so singatures in certificates can be verified
Alternative version with 8 byte subject CN
body: Pick the preferred version and update text accordingly.

title: 202001 address comments
merging profile and encoding sections, but with two TODOs still inlin…
body:
…e to be resolved

John (and maybe Göran), please read and update the merged section as you see fit, while I continue adding example certs, including updating the numbers.

title: added type flag & motivation + changed iot to cert in cbor-iot
body:
The minimal agreed upon updates. 

The motivation for the optional trailing alg. selection field is already present, it seems we missed it: 

"* Signature algorithm. If the signature algorithm is the default it is omitted in the encoding, otherwise encoded as a one byte COSE identifier. This saves 11 or 12 bytes."
